urn:contentItem:570H-DTH1-F0J6-J1SD-00000-00Bushfire conditions worsen near Melbourne2012-11-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Bushfire conditions worsen near MelbourneBEN CUBBY

BUSHFIRE risk has increased sharply since the 1970s, with an index that measures the severity of fire weather conditions near Melbourne having risen nearly 50 per cent in four decades.

A study of weather conditions before bushfires at 38 sites across Australia shows the state capital's score on the Forest Fire Danger Index rose by 49 per cent between 1973 and 2010.

None of the sites, including metropolitan Melbourne and Sydney, were safer from severe fire conditions than they were a generation ago.

The Forest Fire Danger Index, or FFDI, is a points system measuring bushfire risk, from low to catastrophic.

''Fire weather, as depicted by the FFDI, has increased across much of Australia since 1973,'' said the report, produced by researchers at the Climate Change Research Centre at the University of NSW and published in the International Journal of Climatology.

''The largest absolute changes occur in the hot, arid interior of the continent, although some of the largest proportional increases occurred in coastal areas, where average annual cumulative FFDI is relatively low-Melbourne and Adelaide recorded increases of 49 per cent or more over the duration of the record.'' The rating system involves tallying the data on rainfall, evaporation, heat, wind speed and humidity to arrive at a number that signifies the degree of fire risk on any given day.

Conditions such as those preceding the Black Saturday fires, in which 173 people died, are still extremely rare.

''The Black Saturday forest fires of February 2009 . . . were driven by some of the highest FFDI values on record, against a background of severe drought conditions in the preceding months and years,'' the report said. The trend across practically the whole country was for longer fire seasons, and more fires in spring, though not necessarily more fires in summer.

The report also summarised other recent research, and found that inland, south-eastern Australia was seeing the biggest increases in fire danger.

urn:contentItem:5NVH-KKF1-JD34-V3N0-00000-00xxx2017-06-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisNONEPg. 17xxx

If you're looking for a diverse job that involves being outdoors then becoming a Victorian Parks ranger could be the ideal position for you.

Matt White has worked at Parks Victoria as a ranger for the past three years and said the role is extremely rewarding.

"My favourite parts include working with the community, assisting visitors in the park and planned burning," Mr White said.

"My job is both outdoor and indoor, and requires diverse skills, many of which I learnt on the job."

Mr White has a degree in Environmental Science and experience in outdoor education and land surveying.

"A typical day for a ranger in a National Park, State Park or Reserve involves helping visitors with information about walks, safety and the environment," he said.

Rangers keep visitor areas clean and tidy, maintain tracks, trails and infrastructure and implement environmental programs. We also have specialist marine rangers."

However, you don't need a degree to get a job with Parks Victoria.

"Many rangers begin work with Parks Victoria by working as Seasonal Rangers and Project Fire Fighters, seasonal jobs which are advertised most years in Spring," Mr White said.

To kick-start your career and find out more information about jobs and volunteering opportunities across the state, visit the Parks Victoria website www.parks.vic.gov.au or the new ParkConnect volunteer portal   www.parkconnect.vic.gov.au.

Forest Fire Management and Parks Victoria will be exhibiting at the Western Victorian Careers Expo on June 27. They will be providing hands-on interaction with fire vehicles and equipment. The expo is open from 9.30am to 2pm and entry is free.

urn:contentItem:5N8V-8S01-F0J6-J1CB-00000-00Kiwis fly in to help with Victorian burns2017-04-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisKiwis fly in to help with Victorian burns

Up to 40 New Zealand firefighters will fly into Victoria this week to help with the autumn planned burning program.

"We've spoken to neighbouring states and partner agencies but their ability to help is limited due to their own commitments including planned burns. So we're working with New Zealand National Rural Fire Authority to secure short-term additional firefighters to help deliver Victoria's planned burning program," Forest Fire Management Victoria acting chief fire officer Darrin McKenzie said.

"The NZ firefighters will arrive early next week (from April 10) for about 10 days, and will be deployed to the areas where our crews need support during planned burns.

"This is another great opportunity for our crews to work with the New Zealand firefighters and learn from each other.

"The current weather conditions will provide an opportunity to significantly reduce bushfire risk across the state and I want to take every opportunity to get this work done.

"Due to all the vegetation growth we had over the 2016-17 season it is important that we act now to protect Victoria for next summer.

"This week more than 100 planned burns are expected to take place, burning about 70,000 hectares across Victoria. So far, more than 19,000 hectares have been burnt.

"Along with the NZ firefighters, we will continue to work with the CFA to help us deliver this important work."

For the latest information about when planned burns are happening near you go to ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn, download the VicEmergency app or call the VicEmergency hotline on 1800 226 226.

urn:contentItem:5TWY-X7R1-F0J6-J1C7-00000-00City saleyards grass farce2018-12-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4City saleyards grass farceAshleigh McMillan

It's the time of year where hundreds of fire prevention notices are sent out, demanding residents cut their grass. But one council-managed asset is bucking the trend, growing grass over 1.7 metres high.

As Ballarat sweated through 33 degrees celcius on Thursday, business owners near the old Latrobe Street saleyards shared fire safety concerns about the grass on the deserted block.

Ballarat Tractors sits directly across the road from the saleyards on Winter Street, where some of the weeds and grass have grown to impressive heights.

Branch manager Sam Risbey said it was "a bit hypocritical" for council not to ensure its land was fire safe.

"It'd be fairly unlikely for it to impact our tractors, but as it heats up, it would be best if they did something about it," he said. "There's plenty local contractors could be employed and have it cleaned up in a matter of hours if they wanted to."

According to City of Ballarat's website, grass is expected to be no taller than 10 centimetres, with dead undergrowth and fallen branches to be cleaned to prevent flare ups.

Under the CFA Act, residents who do not clean up their properties could be fined 10 penalty units, or around $1661 as of July 2018.

City of Ballarat director of infrastructure and environment Terry Demeo chalked up the unusually tall grass to the continuing transfer of the saleyards.

"The City of Ballarat is currently in the process of transferring management responsibility for the former Latrobe Street saleyards site from previous operators Central Victoria Livestock Exchange (CVLX) to Council," he said in a media response.

"Council will begin to immediately clear and secure the site, including the grass."

A person who works near the saleyards, who spoke to The Courier on the condition of anonymity, said while councils are the first ones to complain about fire risk, the saleyards were a continuous issue.

"It's not just because they've closed it and it's now overgrown, it's always like that," the worker said.

Another nearby employee said that while some sections of the property were mowed recently, other parts near the corner of Learmonth Road and Winter Street were left to grow very long.

CFA chief officer Steve Warrington said in a statement that though rain has made some fuel less flammable in the short-term, the "current weather outlook indicates a return to dry conditions and elevated fire risk".

"While CFA and its partner agencies Parks Victoria, Forest Fire Management ... are doing everything we can to prepare for the bushfire season, we look to the community to use common sense and take responsibility for preventing fires," he said.

urn:contentItem:5FPR-VD31-JB5F-92C2-00000-00Abandoned Dr Seuss house in Alaska a tower of mystery2015-04-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisAbandoned Dr Seuss house in Alaska a tower of mysteryPat Stevens

For anyone who grew up reading Dr Seuss, a hike through the snowy wilderness of Alaska may bring back some magical memories.

Just outside the town of Willow, a small sleepy hamlet about 130 kilometres from Anchorage, stands a structure affectionately known as the Dr Seuss house.

According to design website This is Collossal, the original owner decided to build the home after a forest fire swept through the area. A view of the national park and mountains beyond was the inspiration behind the location.

As the seasons changed and the trees grew again, the owner realised that his view was slowly being blocked by nature

Whether the home will become a tourist attraction or a mecca for Dr Seuss fans only time will tell but the view from the top is absolutely stunning.

Let's just hope it doesn't get too windy in Willow.

urn:contentItem:5NPX-5MF1-F0J6-J0PX-00000-00Seasonal road closures2017-06-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisSeasonal road closures

More tracks and roads across Victoria's state forests and parks will be temporarily closed during winter and spring as part of an annual driver safety and road damage prevention program.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Assistant Chief Fire Officer, Chris Stephenson said: "The main closures for the 2017 Seasonal Road Closure period start on Thursday, June 15, following the initial closure period which began on May 1."

"Seasonal road closures are an important procedure during the winter and spring months and have a two-fold environmental and safety benefit."

"Firstly, this program helps limit the damage done to forest roads and tracks during the wet season and in doing so, ensures dangerous and difficult to negotiate sections of road are closed off from motorists."

"These measures also help maintain water quality in rivers, creeks and reservoirs by reducing the amount of erosion and silt washed away from roads and tracks."

"We encourage the social and recreational use of Victoria's beautiful natural resources, including four-wheel driving, but some sections of the forest road network would rapidly disintegrate if opened for the entire year."

"We consult with a range of stakeholders, including Four Wheel Drive Victoria, to identify sections of the road network which require closures."

"Most of the roads and tracks are re-opened in time for the Melbourne Cup Weekend, but the closure period can be extended if the conditions demand it."

For those wanting to plan their trip, go to the Public Access Map site in the visiting parks and forests section at: www.depi.vic.gov.au/forestry-and-land-use/visiting-parks-and-forests/visiting-state-forests/public-access-map

For maps of the early closures in parks, check the Seasonal Road Closures page on the Parks Victoria website: www.parks.vic.gov.au

Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: EXPERT PLACES FOREST FIRE DAMAGE AT $ US900M $ U</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">JAKARTA, April 19 AFP - Estimates of the financial losses caused by forest fires raging unabated in Indonesia's East Kalimantan province continue to escalate, with one forestry expert now placing the cost at $ US900 million ($ A1.4 billion) dollars.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Dr Abubakar Lahji from the tropical forest rehabilitation centre at the University of Mulawarman in Samarinda said 7.32 trillion rupiah ($1.4 billion) in timber revenues had been lost to the blazes since early this year.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "And this does not include damage to the environment," Lahji was quoted as saying by the state Antara news agency today from the provincial capital of Samarinda.</p><p>Considerable losses of orangutan, birds, insects and rare wildlife have been recorded in the province's Kutai National Park, one of the worst hit areas in the province on the Indonesian section of Borneo island.</p><p> Brief rains in the province last week helped clear up the haze emanating from the fires and reduced the number of "hot spots" to 538, down from nearly 800 earlier in the year, but meteorology officials have said the relief would be brief.</p><p> A "hot spot" is a one-square-kilometre area depicted on satellite images as a single pixel where fire has been detected. However each pixel could have more than one fire.</p><p> The United Nations Disaster Assessment and Coordination team, after a recent visit to the province, estimated that nearly 10,000 fire-fighters would have to be deployed to subdue the blazes.</p><p> The team said that Indonesia no longer had the appropriate resources necessary to fight the fires that have according to government figures wiped out 393,000 hectares of forest in the province this year.</p><p> The drought in the province is expected to drag on for months as the freak El Nino weather pattern threatens to prolong monsoon rains until May at the earliest, meteorologists have predicted.</p><p> Extremely dry conditions have also complicated efforts to extinguish the fires, many of which continue to smoulder underground in peat seams criss-crossing the province.</p><p> Failure to control the blazes has rekindled fears of a repeat of last year's fires that sent a pall of smoke over much of South-East Asia, causing eye, skin and breathing complications and thousands of flight cancellations.</p><p> timber and crop losses were recorded by the end of 1997 after fire damaged some 1.7 million hectares of forest and land,  according to<br/> non-governmental estimates.</p><p>AFP mw</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SGW-S270-0048-T09G-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="410"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:5VBY-2MR1-JD34-V4G7-00000-00Little has changed since Black Saturday bushfire, says expert2019-02-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Little has changed since Black Saturday bushfire, says expertLiam Mannix, Joshua Whittaker and Katharine Haynes

Australians are still ignoring warnings to leave their homes on catastrophic fire days, 10 years after the Black Saturday bushfires left 173 people dead, new nationwide research finds.

And despite a decade of bushfire fighting reforms, another day like Black Saturday could lead to similar numbers of deaths, a top bushfire expert warns. This comes as the Country Fire Authority's top officer warned Victorians: "We won't compromise the safety of our crew when you made a decision to stay there after we'd advised you to leave."

Black Saturday's fires flared up in the worst conditions in Australia's records. On February 7, 2009, a new record maximum temperature of 46.4°C was set in Melbourne, and the forest fire anger index reached 170; far higher than 1983's Ash Wednesday or 1939's Black Saturday.

If we got a repeat of those conditions, we could expect the same number of fatalities, says Professor Ross Bradstock, one of Australia's leading bushfire experts.

"If you were to replay the scenario, the weather, the ignition points and timing, I would say you'd get roughly the same result. All bets are off under those conditions. The sort of weather we saw, it was probably the worst fire weather in the world. It's a turbocharged furnace."

That did not suggest we'd learnt nothing from the disaster.

The bushfire royal commission led to several key changes in the way we warn communities - warnings are sent via SMS and apps almost as soon as fires break out. The biggest change has been the shift in messaging, away from a choice of "stay or go", toward urging people to leave early.

Now official advice on extreme fire danger days is that even the best prepared homes will not be safe, and leaving the night before or early in the day is the safest option.

But research undertaken through the Bushfire & Natural Hazards CRC suggests that while the message may have changed since Black Saturday, people are still choosing to stay even when they are advised to leave.

A significant number of people tell researchers they won't leave until a bushfire breaks out nearby.

The CFA wants to make it very clear: people who do not get out of harm's way cannot expect to be saved. "We made it really clear - we won't be sending a fire truck up your street. We won't compromise the safety of our crew when you made a decision to stay ," says Steve Warrington, the CFA's chief officer.

Dr Josh Whittaker is a bushfire researcher at the University of Wollongong and Dr Katharine Haynes is a human geographer at Macquarie University. Liam Mannix is The Age's science reporter.

urn:contentItem:7V1G-0250-YB64-4004-00000-00Policy critics predicted 'inevitable mega-fires'2009-02-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Policy critics predicted 'inevitable mega-fires'VICTORIA'S DARKEST WEEKANDREW RULE

A GROUP of forest-fire experts has accused state Environment Minister Gavin Jennings of attempting to deceive the public - and of pre-empting a royal commission - over fuel-reduction burning.

Mr Jennings defended the Government over suggestions it had contributed to Australia's worst peacetime disaster by tacitly neglecting its commitment to fuel-reduction burning to appease the green lobby.

Forest Fire Victoria - a group of forestry experts and scientists, including outspoken academic David Packham - claims the Government has sidelined crucial recommendations from its own parliamentary environment and natural resources committee to curry favour with environmentalists.

The dispute flared when Mr Jennings said this week that Victoria had carried out 400,000hectares of fuel-reduction burning over three years - and the proposed royal commission would back his Government's stance.

Mr Packham yesterday accused the minister of deception. "It's true they have done fuel-reduction burning on 400,000 hectares - but everyone else is talking per year and he's talking about burning that much every three years," he said. "If it's not deception, it's stupidity - and I can't believe he (Mr Jennings) is that stupid."

Fuel-reduction burning of 400,000 hectares in three years represented only 1 per cent of Victoria's bushland a year - when 10 per cent was needed to safeguard the state and the Government's own committee had urged an annual minimum of 5 per cent fuel-reduction burning, Mr Packham said.

Mr Packham said he was willing to risk being dismissed from his post as honorary senior research fellow at Monash University's school of geography and environmental science rather than stay silent. It is believed his criticism of bushfire management has made him unpopular in some circles at the university.

Former Victorian environment minister John Thwaites, widely seen as the architect of Victoria's relatively modest reduction-burning policy, has been appointed a professor at Monash since stepping down from Parliament.

Just seven weeks ago, Forest Fire Victoria warned that the apparent failure to act on the recommendations of the Victorian Parliamentary Environment and Natural Resources Committee last June would lead to dangerous fuel loads in Victorian bushland.

Members of Forest Fire Victoria include University of Melbourne botanist (and former forester) Professor Peter Attiwill and the state's former commissioner of forests and, later, chief fire officer, Athol Hodgson.

Mr Hodgson circulated a tough critique of the Government's Living With Fire policy when it was released in mid-December, predicting it would fail and warning that the unprecedented fuel loads in the bush would trigger catastrophic fires.

The parliamentary committee had made 20 recommendations, of which the Government had adopted seven and supported 13 "in principle". "It means they did nothing," Mr Hodgson said.

In his critique, he described the Government's reaction to the committee recommendations as "a farce, conveniently ambiguous and deceptive to the point of arrogance", and paying "lip service only". His colleague, Professor Attiwill, said: "It's a Yes Minister response to avoid doing anything while at the same time appearing to act."

Professor Attiwill said that preventing controlled "ecological burning" in cool autumn weather would inevitably lead to mega-fires.

"Hot fires like that kill things," he said. "If not people, then millions of animals and birds. While all the emphasis is on fire suppression, rather than on fire prevention, it will happen again and again."

urn:contentItem:5VBG-WVS1-DY19-C4BJ-00000-00AFL great Robert Walls at centre of out-of-control bushfire2019-02-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisAFL great Robert Walls at centre of out-of-control bushfirePaul Sakkal

A lightning strike at the home of Carlton legend Robert Walls sparked what eventually became an out-of-control blaze in central Victoria.

A lightning strike at the property of AFL great Robert Walls has sparked what has become an out-of-control bushfire threatening homes in central Victoria.

The Hepburn blaze has destroyed half of Walls' 40-acre property, and an emergency warning is still in place for local residents on Sunday afternoon.

The Carlton legend says the lightning strike happened on Wednesday night, resulting in a small spotfire that was swiftly put out by fire crews.

After apparently smouldering for days after lightning struck, Walls said the fire "just took off" about 6pm on Saturday night, requiring more than 40 trucks and seven choppers to attend the scene.

CFA and Victoria Police confirmed a lighting strike was the likely cause of the fire.

"The fire absolutely tore through the gorge around the property - pretty much 180 degrees around the house," said Walls, who said dead trees and branches provided fuel for the blaze.

"It burned all night - we haven't really slept."

Walls said the steepness of the gorge created difficulty for crews, who weren't able to drive trucks into the eye of the fire.

Victoria's bushfire emergency worsened this afternoon, with homes under threat at Hepburn Springs as well as Grantville in the state's southeast. @SamCucchiara9   #9News   pic.twitter.com/ZyaFsFOsK2

??? Nine News Melbourne (@9NewsMelb) February 3, 2019

The 68-year-old said he believed crews had tamed the blaze early on Sunday, before it worsened again as the morning progressed.

"This morning at 6am it didn't look too bad, then it just took off again."

Walls said he feared for the local community, many of whom have evacuated their homes on advice from the CFA.

"It was really bearing down on properties at Hepburn ... Hepburn could have been gone without [CFA crews'] great work," he said.

Walls, who was alone at his home, said if he left, he would be unable to return to his property at Elevated Plains until the fire subsided.

"There's a southerly wind due later tonight - if it does come back towards the property I'll be heading off," Walls said.

"My car is packed and ready to go."

Walls - who won four premierships with Carlton as player and coach - praised the "incredible bravery" of fire crews.

"The fireys are just amazing," he said.

Overnight, CFA crews defended several properties outside the town.

Tony English, from Forest Fire Management Victoria, said authorities were "preparing for change in conditions at about 5.30pm, which will shift the wind and could cause the fire to become more intense and pick up pace".

An emergency alert remains present for the blaze.

urn:contentItem:5MCK-12J1-JD34-V51H-00000-00BREAKING: Fire at Meredith2016-12-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisBREAKING: Fire at MeredithMichael Pollock

UPDATE: 7.30pm

A statement from the CFA confirmed the fire is still not under control.

Crews are assisting the Department of Environment, Water, Land and Planning (DEWLP) fight the fire.

More than 20 CFA trucks are on the scene, with firefighting aircraft providing further assistance.

Firefighters are protecting one home located in the forest and are working to contain the fire in bushland.

District 7 rostered duty officer Mark Collins said hot and windy weather forecast tomorrow will require crews to monitor the incident overnight.

"We're working closely with DEWLP to keep an eye on this forest fire because we've got bad weather conditions expected tomorrow," he said.

An advice message has been issued, assuring no threat to communities, however advising residents in the area to monitor weather conditions, review your fire plan and keep roads clear for emergency service vehicles.

BEFORE

Fire crews are responding to a serious blaze in Meredith.

More than 30 vehicles have been sent to tackle one blaze located along Slate Quarry Road, according to the Vic Emergency Website.

The site lists another, separate, bushfire in the area - with 14 vehicles reported as attending, but it's still unclear if the fires are part of one larger blaze.

Both fires are listed as 'not yet under control'.

One of the fires is listed as travelling in a easterly direction towards She Oaks, Maude.

Residents in Lethbridge, Maude, Meredith and She Oaks are advised to be wary of the current situation.

CFA has been contacted for more information.

urn:contentItem:5RJD-HC91-JD34-V3WS-00000-00Australia Day 2018: Committed career in fire management rewarded with honour2018-01-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Australia Day 2018: Committed career in fire management rewarded with honourNatalie Croxon

A CAREER in the environmental and emergency management fields spanning 38 years has seen Russell Manning awarded the Australian Fire Service Medal this Australia Day.

Mr Manning, who is a former Wimmera fire manager, said he was honoured to receive the accolade, not just for himself but on behalf of the public land firefighting staff who do a "great job".

"I'm really passionate about the work that we do," Mr Manning said.

"I really like the emergency management space and working in teams in emergency management situations to protect our communities."

Mr Manning, a Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning project manager based in Bendigo, started his career in the works crew at Wyperfeld National Park in the Mallee.

Growing up in the small town of Rainbow, he always enjoyed being outside and his career was no doubt influenced by his parents, both of whom volunteered with the Country Fire Authority.

Mr Manning's career has taken him across the state, with stints in Horsham, Melbourne, Gippsland and the Mallee.

He worked as the district fire manager in the Wimmera and Mallee between 2009 and 2017.

Other roles have included assistant ranger, ranger-in-charge, Forest Fire district manager, incident controller and operations officer.

His work has not been restricted to in Victoria: he has participated in emergency deployments to the USA to assist in fighting fires, and in 2011 went to Christchurch in New Zealand to help in the wake of the city's disastrous earthquake.

Looking forward to the future, Mr Manning would like to help bring through the next generation of firefighters.

"What I'd like to be doing in... the next five years is to be more involved in mentoring and training incident control staff," he said.

A statement of Mr Manning's achievements in relation to the Australia Fire Service Medal said he was especially committed to collaborating with other agencies.

"His leadership in this area has enabled excellent cross agency responses to major fire events with great benefits to the community of Victoria," it read.

urn:contentItem:5RGK-70M1-JD34-V3HD-00000-00Horsham Incident Control Centre upgrades boost emergency response2018-01-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisHorsham Incident Control Centre upgrades boost emergency responseStuart McGuckin

EMERGENCY services are better placed to cohesively respond to natural disasters with the latest upgrades to the Horsham Incident Control Centre.

Leaders officially opened the upgraded centre, at Grains Innovation Park, on Wednesday.

Work, worth $1.65 million, went towards improving radio, telephone and data communications infrastructure.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Wimmera district manager Glenn Rudolph said the high level of people co-ordinating the Grampians Northern Complex fires response in 2014 provided the catalyst for the upgrades.

The centre underwent renovations during winter and has operated at its increased capacity since September.

"It became apparent then, with the number of organisations that we had to host in here, that it wasn't enough space," Mr Rudolph said.

"We were very fortunate to have some senior people here at the time and they advocated for it.

"There are a lot more people coming in here to help manage things then there was in the past."

Energy, Environment and Climate Change Minister Lily D'Ambrosio was on hand to help officially re-open the centre.

"We're improving the ability of all major emergency agencies to more effectively respond to large and complex incidents in Western Victoria," she said.

"The Horsham Incident Control Centre is one of the largest in the state covering about 2.7 million hectares - this upgrade is a vital step in better managing severe fire and floods."

The upgrades involved significant layout changes in order to more comfortably accommodate for people involved in helping during big incidents.

"There is much more space for emergency management partners to come in now as well," Mr Rudolph said.

"We have see quite a number of significant incidents over the past decade or so since the centre was initially built in 2002. The extent of those incidents and in terms of what we have to manage in this part of the world we felt there was a need to have better facilities here."

The Wimmera has experienced 11 level-three fires and two floods since 2004 while the incident control centre has also managed 10 fires that have burnt more than 1000 hectares.

urn:contentItem:5T1W-FSC1-JD34-V31V-00000-00Second North East Vic Emergency Services Expo to run in October2018-08-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisSecond North East Vic Emergency Services Expo to run in OctoberEllen Ebsary

The North East Victoria Emergency Services Expo is returning for the second time, with 20 organisations to be represented at Moyhu in October.

The inaugural event at Whorouly in 2016 was attended by about 120 people, and organiser Carina Heppell said this year's expo would be "10 times bigger".

"It's now extended to the North East and we're expecting 500 to 1000 people," she said.

"We're not only there to show people what's available, but to learn from their experiences and see how we can help them in the future.

"After the Whorouly event, there were floods two months later and we heard stories from the kids, who were telling us the things they learned from the expo helped them during the floods."

There will be demonstrations, a sandbagging arena, displays and emergency gear such as lighting for sale, with a gold coin donation and raffle proceeds going to CFA brigades in the Moyhu area.

Ms Heppell, an SES community education facilitator, said there would be food and family activities on offer.

"It's something for the whole family," she said.

"We're aiming to be plastic-wise as well - there will be no balloons or plastic bags, and as it's an agricultural area, we won't be encouraging people to bring their pets."

Youngsters will be able to dress up in the bright green uniform of Forest Fire Management Victoria, who are new to the expo this year.

Ovens district community partnerships support officer Ben Merritt will be bringing FFMV's latest technology, including the all-terrain G-Wagon and the $450,000 Unimog, both equipped with falling object protection.

"The Unimog is something people don't see a great deal of as most of our work is in the bush, out in the hills and well away from public access," he said.

"This is a good opportunity for us to show off this new technology that helps us fight fires more efficiently."

Mr Merritt hoped to establish a stronger connection with residents.

"We'll be providing advice on fire, there will be other agencies there talking about flood and storm, and mental health is another issue that we'll be talking about on the day," he said.

"The main emphasis is it's for the community."

The North East Victoria Emergency Services Expo will take place at the Moyhu Recreation Reserve on Saturday, October 6 from 10am to 2pm.

urn:contentItem:5RJD-DSB1-F0J6-J3PM-00000-00Australia Day 2018: Committed career in fire management rewarded with honour2018-01-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisAustralia Day 2018: Committed career in fire management rewarded with honourNatalie Croxon

A CAREER in the environmental and emergency management fields spanning 38 years has seen Russell Manning awarded the Australian Fire Service Medal this Australia Day.

Mr Manning, who is a former Wimmera fire manager, said he was honoured to receive the accolade, not just for himself but on behalf of the public land firefighting staff who do a "great job".

"I'm really passionate about the work that we do," Mr Manning said.

"I really like the emergency management space and working in teams in emergency management situations to protect our communities."

Mr Manning, a Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning project manager based in Bendigo, started his career in the works crew at Wyperfeld National Park in the Mallee.

Growing up in the small town of Rainbow, he always enjoyed being outside and his career was no doubt influenced by his parents, both of whom volunteered with the Country Fire Authority.

Mr Manning's career has taken him across the state, with stints in Horsham, Melbourne, Gippsland and the Mallee.

He worked as the district fire manager in the Wimmera and Mallee between 2009 and 2017.

Other roles have included assistant ranger, ranger-in-charge, Forest Fire district manager, incident controller and operations officer.

His work has not been restricted to in Victoria: he has participated in emergency deployments to the USA to assist in fighting fires, and in 2011 went to Christchurch in New Zealand to help in the wake of the city's disastrous earthquake.

Looking forward to the future, Mr Manning would like to help bring through the next generation of firefighters.

"What I'd like to be doing in... the next five years is to be more involved in mentoring and training incident control staff," he said.

A statement of Mr Manning's achievements in relation to the Australia Fire Service Medal said he was especially committed to collaborating with other agencies.

"His leadership in this area has enabled excellent cross agency responses to major fire events with great benefits to the community of Victoria," it read.

urn:contentItem:5W8F-MCT1-F0JP-W2GM-00000-00Can't bear to lose this2019-06-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Can't bear to lose thisBRENDAN O'MALLEY editorial@citysouthnews.com.au

Council, State Government at odds on Toohey Forest fire management plan Call to open up pouches Spat over whether council or state should pay for koala land

A SPAT has broken out between the State Government and Brisbane City Council over the fate of koala habitat on the southern edge of Toohey Forest.

Councillor Steve Griffiths (Moorooka) called on the LNP administration to use its beefed-up bushland fund to buy the land, on the Nathan side of the reserve.

He made the call after the LNP brought a motion in chambers on Tuesday which asked for the government to essentially gift the land to council.

But the State Government has dug in, insisting council pay for it using its bushland fund.

Local State MP, Mark Bailey, denied the government wanted to sell the land but said it had a responsibility to maintain firebreaks.

The spat comes ahead of a public tour of the site this weekend. "I have launched a petition calling on council to negotiate with the state using its bushland protection funds to acquire this property," Cr Griffiths said.

"Council gave the government approval to clear for firebreaks, although approval was not needed," Cr Griffiths said.

"I was told by officers that they originally wanted to clear 20 per cent, which is extreme, but they have phased that back.

"We're now working with (the government) on a fire management regime instead of clearing." Mr Bailey said the land, owned by Economic Development Queensland (EDQ), was next to Toohey Forest but not part of it.

"These blocks of land near Griffith University at Nathan have been publicly owned since at least 1994 when I was chair of the then Toohey Forest Management Committee," he said.

"I'm advised by the department there are no plans to clear them or to sell them. "As a land owner in the greater Toohey Forest area, the state department has (fire management) responsibilities it takes seriously to minimise fuel load and risks to fauna from a bush fire." Mr Bailey said in 1998, when he was the local councillor, he negotiated for the council to buy the last large privately-owned parcel of Toohey Forest still at risk of development, the 13ha Mayne Estate.

Council bought the land, north of Mayfield Rd, for about $1.5 million after attempts by then Lady Mayoress Sallyanne Atkinson to buy the land so council could extend Mayfield Rd.

"The Mayne Estate was then zoned 'conservation' and locked away as forest for future generations, which I still regard as one of my most significant local achievements as a local representative," Mr Bailey said. "As a former chair of the Toohey Forest Management Committee for nine years, I have a strong local record of protecting and enhancing the environmental values of Toohey Forest, which I remain as strongly committed to now as ever.

"If the current Brisbane City Council wishes to purchase the blocks of land under their Bushland Acquisition Program, along similar lines to how the Mayne Estate was purchased in 1998, then any such proposal would certainly be carefully considered by the State Government." The land is currently zoned special education.

About 100 people have signed Cr Griffiths' petition (https://www.epetitions. brisbane.qld.gov.au/petition/view/pid/704).Planning minister Cameron Dick's office said EDQ had an obligation to maintain firebreaks on its land, consistent with a 10-year approval issued by council in August, 2017.

urn:contentItem:5PJS-7641-F0JP-W0TD-00000-00Out-of-control burn-off fears2017-09-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Out-of-control burn-off fearsBarry Kennedy

FIREFIGHTERS got a taste of what to expect across Sunbury and the Macedon Ranges this summer after a private burn-off got out of control in Tylden.

Tylden, Kyneton, Trentham, Woodend and Carlsruhe CFA crews joined -forces to put out the 8.1ha fire which started after a landowner burned off the -remains of a former blue gum plantation.

Tylden CFA captain Liam Miles said the September 18 fire was hard to access and high winds added to the difficulties for firefighters.

"We haven't had to attend a burn-off like this for a number of years," he said. "The former plantation had been cut down. It seemed the property owner's idea was to dispose of the -remnants with a fire. Burn-offs have to be -registered and weather -conditions monitored in the lead-up and on the day of the planned burn." The blaze comes after the region was declared as -having "significant fire -potential" in the Southern Australia Seasonal Bushfire Outlook, released by the -Bureau of Meteorology in consultation with fire and land managers.

Victorian Emergency Management Commissioner Craig Lapsley said preparations were already under way for this year's fire season.

"The early forecast shows there is underlying dryness in some areas of the state, particularly across central parts of Victoria and across the east," he said.

Works to prepare for the season have included Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA bringing forward planned burns.

Mr Lapsley urged residents to start their fire prevention works and "get ready and prepare your properties, yourself and your family".

CFA North Western -community safety manager David Allen said preparations were stepping up across Sunbury and the -Macedon Ranges.The Hesket-Kerrie and Benloch communities are taking part in the State Government-supported Safer -Together program, where they will work on strategies with the DELWP, Parks Victoria, CFA and Macedon Ranges Council.

urn:contentItem:5T1W-FSC1-JD34-V35P-00000-00Second North East Vic Emergency Services Expo to run in October2018-08-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Second North East Vic Emergency Services Expo to run in OctoberEllen Ebsary

The North East Victoria Emergency Services Expo is returning for the second time, with 20 organisations to be represented at Moyhu in October.

The inaugural event at Whorouly in 2016 was attended by about 120 people, and organiser Carina Heppell said this year's expo would be "10 times bigger".

"It's now extended to the North East and we're expecting 500 to 1000 people," she said.

"We're not only there to show people what's available, but to learn from their experiences and see how we can help them in the future.

"After the Whorouly event, there were floods two months later and we heard stories from the kids, who were telling us the things they learned from the expo helped them during the floods."

There will be demonstrations, a sandbagging arena, displays and emergency gear such as lighting for sale, with a gold coin donation and raffle proceeds going to CFA brigades in the Moyhu area.

Ms Heppell, an SES community education facilitator, said there would be food and family activities on offer.

"It's something for the whole family," she said.

"We're aiming to be plastic-wise as well - there will be no balloons or plastic bags, and as it's an agricultural area, we won't be encouraging people to bring their pets."

Youngsters will be able to dress up in the bright green uniform of Forest Fire Management Victoria, who are new to the expo this year.

Ovens district community partnerships support officer Ben Merritt will be bringing FFMV's latest technology, including the all-terrain G-Wagon and the $450,000 Unimog, both equipped with falling object protection.

"The Unimog is something people don't see a great deal of as most of our work is in the bush, out in the hills and well away from public access," he said.

"This is a good opportunity for us to show off this new technology that helps us fight fires more efficiently."

Mr Merritt hoped to establish a stronger connection with residents.

"We'll be providing advice on fire, there will be other agencies there talking about flood and storm, and mental health is another issue that we'll be talking about on the day," he said.

"The main emphasis is it's for the community."

The North East Victoria Emergency Services Expo will take place at the Moyhu Recreation Reserve on Saturday, October 6 from 10am to 2pm.

urn:contentItem:5RGK-70M1-JD34-V3H3-00000-00Horsham Incident Control Centre upgrades boost emergency response2018-01-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisHorsham Incident Control Centre upgrades boost emergency responseStuart McGuckin

EMERGENCY services are better placed to cohesively respond to natural disasters with the latest upgrades to the Horsham Incident Control Centre.

Leaders officially opened the upgraded centre, at Grains Innovation Park, on Wednesday.

Work, worth $1.65 million, went towards improving radio, telephone and data communications infrastructure.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Wimmera district manager Glenn Rudolph said the high level of people co-ordinating the Grampians Northern Complex fires response in 2014 provided the catalyst for the upgrades.

The centre underwent renovations during winter and has operated at its increased capacity since September.

"It became apparent then, with the number of organisations that we had to host in here, that it wasn't enough space," Mr Rudolph said.

"We were very fortunate to have some senior people here at the time and they advocated for it.

"There are a lot more people coming in here to help manage things then there was in the past."

Energy, Environment and Climate Change Minister Lily D'Ambrosio was on hand to help officially re-open the centre.

"We're improving the ability of all major emergency agencies to more effectively respond to large and complex incidents in Western Victoria," she said.

"The Horsham Incident Control Centre is one of the largest in the state covering about 2.7 million hectares - this upgrade is a vital step in better managing severe fire and floods."

The upgrades involved significant layout changes in order to more comfortably accommodate for people involved in helping during big incidents.

"There is much more space for emergency management partners to come in now as well," Mr Rudolph said.

"We have see quite a number of significant incidents over the past decade or so since the centre was initially built in 2002. The extent of those incidents and in terms of what we have to manage in this part of the world we felt there was a need to have better facilities here."

The Wimmera has experienced 11 level-three fires and two floods since 2004 while the incident control centre has also managed 10 fires that have burnt more than 1000 hectares.

urn:contentItem:5RGC-FTP1-F0JP-W2KY-00000-00SLEEPLESS NIGHT AS MASSIVE BLAZE THREATENS2018-01-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3SLEEPLESS NIGHT AS MASSIVE BLAZE THREATENSLIANA TURNER AND NIKKI TODD

FIREFIGHTERS were last night backburning in the path of a huge scrub fire near Cudgen to prevent it spreading further south.

At deadline, some Tweed residents were set for a sleepless night after being urged to prepare for evacuation.

Police and emergency services doorknocked homes and businesses, including the popular Tropical Fruit World, at 1.30pm as it threatened to burn out of control.

Mother-of-two Julie-Anne (surname withheld) said she received a call at work on the Gold Coast from her teenage kids after police knocked on their door of their Melaleuca Rd property.

"It was a very long 40 minutes on the drive home," she said, estimating flames came within 500m of their house, before the wind turned and firefighters got it under control.

"It's pretty scary, we won't be getting a lot of sleep tonight. If the fire jumps over to the next-door neighbour's where there are a lot of trees, if that goes up we'll be in trouble.

"The car is packed and we are ready to go if we need to." At its peak yesterday, 10 fire trucks and about 30 firefighters were working to contain the grass blaze which burned through 100 hectares on the Tweed Coast.

Incident controller Jared Lee said crews would be at the scene throughout the night, having first been called to the Kings Forest fire at 10.45am.

"We are backburning to strengthen control lines but it is contained," he said, adding it was not a threat to homes.

Tropical Fruit World general manager Aymon Gow said more than 200 guests and staff were evacuated from the farm around 1.30pm as north-easterly winds began to blow the blaze in their direction.

"It's better to be safe than sorry and we decided to get everyone up and out of the park," Mr Gow said.

"It's the first time in 30 years the park has been around that we have had to evacuate."It is understood the fire was ignited by a car which stopped on the side of Depot Rd after it began to overheat.

urn:contentItem:5XSG-7XH1-JCM0-61K8-00000-00NSW bushfires burn an area greater than Wales, the result of an exceptional spring2019-12-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisNSW bushfires burn an area greater than Wales, the result of an exceptional springKate Doyle

Bushfires this season have officially burnt the most land on modern record across eastern New South Wales.

In a special climate statement released on Wednesday, the Bureau of Meteorology said spring 2019 saw Australia's highest fire weather danger on record.

Even by the end of spring, the extent of the fires this season was exceptional; more than 1.65 million hectares had been burnt in New South Wales.

On December 9, NSW Rural Fire Service Commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons tweeted that fires had burnt about 2.7 million hectares - an area greater than Wales.

Yes, Wales, the country.

Or if sport is more your thing, one hectare is approximately the size of a soccer pitch.

Between early September and the end of November, 220,000 hectares had been burnt in Queenslandand still the fires rage on.

Fires have already occurred in every state and territory this season.

Normally, it would now only be the beginning of the fire season in the southern states, and traditionally the northern fire season would be winding down as summer rains arrived, but there is no indication that rain is coming any time soon.

Fire danger unprecedented

Responsibility for the death penalty I FIND it hypocritical of our Federal Government to say it opposes the death penalty. These men were trying to smuggle drugs into Australia, not Indonesia, so why not arrest them here? Instead, the Government allowed the Australian Federal Police to inform the Indonesian authorities about them, knowing they could be executed there. I do not condone drug smuggling or executions, but in my opinion the AFP is the firing squad in this case.

GERRY COLEMAN, Bassendean PERHAPS Tom Percy (Insight, February 1) hasn't experienced a family destroyed by drugs. Myuran Sukumaran and Andrew Chan knew exactly what they were doing and the only reason they are "rehabilitated" is they got caught. Joe Spagnolo is exactly right in saying they should be executed. A lot of families have been saved because these men were caught; why should we save them?

BETTY BLENNERHASSETT, Waikiki MY sympathy goes to the parents and relatives of these men and my question to them is: Boys, how could you so selfishly do this to your loved ones for the sake of a few dollars?

R.L. PASS, The Vines

No-fault insurance WHEN will our Government stop dragging its feet in implementing no-fault insurance? Does it really take a White Paper, a Green Paper, numerous surveys and all the rest when a decent, sensible idea is mooted? Any one of us could be affected by an accident (regardless of fault or circumstances) with all the attendant after-effects - physical, mental, social and financial. Just do it.

HELEN WILLIAMS, Boyanup

Political pointers THE election results in Queensland and the way the Federal Government stands in the polls are sure indications this country is on the skids. The treacle stick syndrome has taken over and the only governments we are going to elect in future are those that promise to pander to the wants and needs of those on welfare. If you think things are tough now, just wait until our governments (of whichever party) are forced to sell off every asset that belongs to Australia just to pay our way from day to day. You ain't seen nothin' yet.

D.P. BANNER, Coolbellup

Wonky welfare BRENDAN McAssey, CEO of high-end childcare company Only About Children, says means testing for childcare rebates is unfair, because living costs are so high in the richer suburbs where his centres are located, and where fees are as high as $170 a day, or up to $850 a week. Disability pensioners get $470 a week. It seems the richer you are, the more welfare money you need.

Name and address supplied

Forest fires DFES needs to wake up. If any forest fire (Northcliffe is a forest fire, not a bushfire) occurs in 35C-plus conditions, all notices should be to residents to get out. Bringing in more firefighters is useless; all it does is create more risk of human injuries.BERT PAYNTER, Katanning

1 YARRA RANGES Yarra Ranges police are reminding commuters PSOs are now patrolling platforms and trains. Officers have the power to arrest and detain, search people and property, seize weapons, graffiti implements, alcohol, and hand out fines.

2 LILYDALE Victoria Police is appealing for help to find Darren Butler. The 40-year-old is about 190cm, with a medium build, short brown spiky hair and blue eyes. Police have reported he has tattoos on both hands and forearms. Police believe the man is known to visit Lilydale, Yarra Glen and St Kilda. Anyone with information or who sees the man is urged to phone Crime Stoppers.

3 MT DANDENONG Cyclists are urged to avoid riding Mt Dandenong Tourist Rd as authorities burned 8.9ha of land in the Dandenong Ranges. The planned burn could delay drivers near Kalorama on October 30. Forest Fire Management Victoria spokesman Dan White said Mt Dandenong was a prominent landmark, so the smoke could have been visible from various parts of the Melbourne and to motorists on the Eastern Freeway and EastLink. "We are taking advantage of ideal conditions to do this burn and help reduce fire risk to nearby communities ahead of summer," Mr White said. Details: ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn or download the Vic Emergency app.

4 UPPER FERNTREE GULLY Police are handing out 10 to 15 parking fines each time they patrol the 1000 steps. Knox highway patrol unit commander Sergeant David Young said they had huge problems with people double parking, parking on the hairpin bend, and in bus bays. "When the weather comes good, everyone loves to come up there and exercise and socialise and it's a very popular place but it's got limited parking," Sgt Young said. "It's a real risk, we're coming into fire season, if there is a fire in the Dandenongs we need to be able to access these roads without cars parked in no standing areas or on blind corners. Illegal parkers face fines of $161.

5 YARRA RANGES VicRoads is warning drivers to slow down and take extra care in wet and windy weather. Recent severe weather warnings around Victoria, prompted the road authority to urge people to be vigilant and make sure there were no distractions to take their eyes from the road. Drivers were reminded to leave extra space between them and the car in front, be sure to turn headlights on, and be extra vigilant for cyclists and motorbikes which are difficult to see. If the rain gets too heavy for windscreen wipers to cope, pull over safely and wait for the rain to pass.

urn:contentItem:5TM1-CGY1-F0JP-W1NT-00000-00Street Watch2018-10-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisSTREETWATCHPg. 7Street Watch

1 YARRA JUNCTION A burn-off reignited and escaped in the Yarra Valley with about seven firefighting crews called in to stop the flames. The report on the Wesburn Millgrove CFA Facebook page said volunteers from around the valley including Yarra Junction, Yellingbo, Hoddles Creek and Gruyere attended a smoke sighting near Station St in Wesburn. Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighters were already on scene and the fire was burning freely on two properties after escaping a burn-off from two days prior. The post said the burn off had soil pushed over it by a machine but had taken off again during light winds on Thursday, October 25. It took six hours to fully extinguish the fire. The post warned the community the fire burnt through what is normally a wet gully during low rated fire conditions. "I think it's time the local residents realise, yes the grass is green but the forest is as dry as it ever has been for this time of year and restrictions will soon be in for what could be a very long fire season," the post warned. "Don't wait until a date is set for the fire declared period clean up now and be on the front foot, have a tested fire plan for your family and pets."

2 KILSTYH A scary road rage incident is being investigated by police after a car was rammed in Kilsyth. Police are appealing for witnesses and dashcam footage to identify the 4WD (pictured) that rammed another car three times on Canterbury Rd, between Mt Dandenong and Liverpool roads at 11pm on October 19. Police believe the driver of the 4WD then performed a U-turn over a median strip and drove away toward Montrose. Anyone with information or who witnessed the incident is urged to contact Mooroolbark police on 9725 9999 or Crime Stoppers.

3 MOOROOLBARK The victim of a hit run in the Chirnside Park shopping centre car park is being searched for after a P-plate driver accidentally knocked a stationary ute and drove away. Mooroolbark police Senior Constable Colleen Toomey said the probationary driver came in with her parents to chat with police shortly after the incident at about 2pm on Sunday, October 7. Sen-Constable Toomey said police wanted to find the driver of the damaged ute, parked near Kmart. Any witnesses or anyone with information is urged to contact Mooroolbark police.

4 YARRA RANGES The outer east community is being called on for help after a folder with vintage photos and drawings was handed in to police. The hessian item was given to Croydon police after being discovered on Alto Ave. Anyone with information should phone 9724 0100.

Or if sport is more your thing, one hectare is approximately the size of a soccer pitch.

Between early September and the end of November, 220,000 hectares had been burnt in Queenslandand still the fires rage on.

"More than 95 per cent of Australia by area had spring-accumulated FFDI values that were very much above average (highest 10 per cent of years), including almost 60 per cent of the country that was highest on record for spring," the report stated.

As a general rule, fires west of the Great Dividing Range are often more widespread, but because of lower fuel loads they burn with a lower intensity.

Fires on or east of the range, in more densely forested areas, burn with a greater intensity; when that intensity is combined with higher population density, there is greater risk.

According to the report, the closest season compared to 2019 was 1968, but even it was less extensive than this year.

Those fires also took place under severe drought conditions and were limited to the Hunter and Illawarra regions.

The 1968 season had a number of major fires, including one in the Blue Mountains that burnt for more than a month - the Australian Disaster Resilience Knowledge Hub attributes the Blue Mountains and Illawarra bushfire with burning through 1.5 million hectares.

Other major fires in eastern NSW include:

January 1994, when 800,000 hectares burnt around Sydney and the state's north-east

Christmas 2001, when 750,000 hectares burnt on the southern fringes of Sydney and around the ACT, bringing significant smoke

October 2013, most remembered for its rapid onset and significant loss of homes in the Blue Mountains

With the current heat event, South Australia is bracing for dangerous fire conditions until a cool change late Friday.

The worst of the fire danger is then expected to return to New South Wales on Saturday ahead of the change, with continued elevated fire danger in Queensland.

This week's update to the bushfire outlook didn't bring much in the way of good news.

urn:contentItem:59B0-FS11-JD34-V388-00000-00Bushfires rage early2013-09-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Bushfires rage earlyPeter Hannam

Sydney's early fire season was no big surprise for authorities and nor should

it be for the wider public - had we been paying heed to scientists' warnings. These

warnings applied equally to Victoria.

On Sydney's north-western fringe on Tuesday, firefighters were in running battles to

save lives and homes as the bushfire season began with terrifying swiftness.

With temperatures above 30 degrees, fires fanned by north-westerly winds meant

otherwise containable grass fires quickly turned into fastmoving infernos.

By 6pm, 63 fires were burning across NSW, 31 of them uncontained.

Two homes were lost at Winmalee in the Blue Mountains, and Marsden Park in the Blacktown area, and fires raged in suburbs including Castleraegh, near

Penrith, and Windsor.

Two firefighters had to be treated for burns and five others required treatment

for serious smoke inhalation. Another was taken to hospital with chest pains.

Experts at the CSIRO, the Bureau of Meteorology and elsewhere have found

Australia's fi re seasons are starting earlier and ending later. Climate change is

probably behind the shift.

Last week, the Bushfire Cooperative Research Centre warned in its Southern

Australia Bushfi re Outlook that most of eastern NSW, ACT and western Victoria

could expect above-average fire activity this summer.

Fire weather as judged by the forest fire danger index rose the most between 1973

and 2010 in south and southeast Australia, with some of the largest proportional

increases in coastal areas. Melbourne and Adelaide had an index rise of 49 per cent

or more. Drought, especially in Victoria in regions from Laverton to Mildura, was

seen as a signifi cant factor in the rising index.

Anthony Clark, a spokesman for NSW's Rural Fire Service, said it was unusual to see fires burning with so much intensity so early.

Chris Lucas, a researcher at the Centre for Australian Weather and Climate

Research, said a large trend towards higher forest fire danger readings was clear

in south-east Australia, including around Sydney.

Key factors are drier winters and higher temperatures. Sydney and much of NSW are in for a tough summer with the city posting its mildest winter and highest year-to-date temperatures in more than 150 years of records.

PHOTO: Firefighters abandon a truck as the fire burns out of control on Londonderry Road in Sydney's northwestern suburbs. Photo: Nick Moir

urn:contentItem:5PDY-DP71-F0J6-J3X2-00000-00Wimmera bushfire risk 'normal' for summer2017-09-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisNEWSWimmera bushfire risk 'normal' for summerErin Witmitz

WIMMERA firefighters have encouraged residents to prepare for this year's fire season, despite a wet winter.

The Bushfire and Natural Hazards Co-operative Research Centre has released its Southern Australia Seasonal Bushfire Outlook 2017, which shows the Wimmera will have 'normal' bushfire potential this summer.

This is down from an 'above normal' risk in the region for the past few summers.

The research centre predicts that most of central and eastern Victoria will have a high risk of bushfires for 2017-18.

The report said severe rainfall deficiencies in southern forest areas and the Bureau of Meteorology's outlook for drier and warmer conditions in spring, gave rise to an expectation of above normal fire potential.

"Good prospects for spring growth in the northern and central western grain growing areas present a risk of an early fire season, as these areas are expected to increase biomass during spring and cure during October," the report said.

"This will happen as available soil water becomes depleted."

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Wimmera district manager Glenn Rudolph said while across Victoria the outlook was for an above average bushfire season, the Wimmera had experienced widespread rain across most of the year. "We've had above-average rainfall last month, but despite that, it is difficult to predict the fire risk," he said.

"We are also conscious of the fact that the average season and the rain we have had could increase grass growth in spring.

"The Bureau of Meteorology is also predicting above average temperatures for spring." Mr Rudolph said despite the bushfire outlook, people should always be prepared for the fire season.

"You can never predict what is going to happen and every year there is a risk of bushfires, regardless of the forecast," he said.

"My message to everyone is to be aware of the risks, especially when travelling across the state."

Those fires also took place under severe drought conditions and were limited to the Hunter and Illawarra regions.

The 1968 season had a number of major fires, including one in the Blue Mountains that burnt for more than a month - the Australian Disaster Resilience Knowledge Hub attributes the Blue Mountains and Illawarra bushfire with burning through 1.5 million hectares.

Other major fires in eastern NSW include:

January 1994, when 800,000 hectares burnt around Sydney and the state's north-east

Christmas 2001, when 750,000 hectares burnt on the southern fringes of Sydney and around the ACT, bringing significant smoke

October 2013, most remembered for its rapid onset and significant loss of homes in the Blue Mountains

With the current heat event, South Australia is bracing for dangerous fire conditions until a cool change late Friday.

The worst of the fire danger is then expected to return to New South Wales on Saturday ahead of the change, with continued elevated fire danger in Queensland.

This week's update to the bushfire outlook didn't bring much in the way of good news.

Keep up to date with warnings from your local fire authority, ABC Radio and ABC Emergency on Facebook.

urn:contentItem:5PDY-DP71-F0J6-J3BC-00000-00Wimmera bushfire risk 'normal' for summer2017-09-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisWimmera bushfire risk 'normal' for summerErin Witmitz

WIMMERA firefighters have encouraged residents to prepare for this year's fire season, despite a wet winter.

The Bushfire and Natural Hazards Co-operative Research Centre has released its Southern Australia Seasonal Bushfire Outlook 2017, which shows the Wimmera will have 'normal' bushfire potential this summer.

This is down from an 'above normal' risk in the region for the past few summers.

The research centre predicts that most of central and eastern Victoria will have a high risk of bushfires for 2017-18.

The report said severe rainfall deficiencies in southern forest areas and the Bureau of Meteorology's outlook for drier and warmer conditions in spring, gave rise to an expectation of above normal fire potential.

"Good prospects for spring growth in the northern and central western grain growing areas present a risk of an early fire season, as these areas are expected to increase biomass during spring and cure during October," the report said.

"This will happen as available soil water becomes depleted."

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Wimmera district manager Glenn Rudolph said while across Victoria the outlook was for an above average bushfire season, the Wimmera had experienced widespread rain across most of the year. "We've had above-average rainfall last month, but despite that, it is difficult to predict the fire risk," he said.

"We are also conscious of the fact that the average season and the rain we have had could increase grass growth in spring.

"The Bureau of Meteorology is also predicting above average temperatures for spring." Mr Rudolph said despite the bushfire outlook, people should always be prepared for the fire season.

"You can never predict what is going to happen and every year there is a risk of bushfires, regardless of the forecast," he said.

"My message to everyone is to be aware of the risks, especially when travelling across the state."

urn:contentItem:5RB9-PPG1-JD34-V42W-00000-00Warnings issued as hottest day in 11 months predicted2018-01-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisWarnings issued as hottest day in 11 months predictedSophie Boyd

Victoria is in a state of total fire ban, with Saturday forecast to be the hottest day on the Border or North East in almost 11 months.

Gusts of 20 to 30 kilometres an hour have also been predicted.

The Bureau of Meterology forecast most Border and North East towns would reach 41 degrees on Saturday and 38 on Sunday, before temperatures return to the mid-30s.

It will be the first time the temperature jump over the 40-degree mark since February 10 last year, when the mercury spiked at 43.7 degrees.

A NSW's Rural Fire Service spokesman said they were watching forecasts, especially wind levels, closely in areas of severe fire danger but no total fire ban had been declared yet.

Communities have already felt the impact of the impending heat with one small town's big event, the Dederang Cup, abandoned for the first time in at least 63 years, due the weather.

A Victorian government Heat Health Alert issued for parts of the state urges residents to drink water and check on vulnerable people.

Forest Fire Management Victoria warned residents it is illegal to light a campfire on a total fire ban day.

Assistant Chief Fire Officer for the Hume Region Gill Metz said the region was expecting wind gusts up to 30 kilometres an hour across Saturday.

"Historically in the Hume region, we've had far too many bushfires caused by campfire negligence and this is placing the community, firefighters and the environment at risk," she said.

"It's critically important campfire safety is a priority."

Already this year a number of unattended campfires were located and extinguished.

"Under the right conditions, anyone of these campfires could have become a bushfire and threaten lives, property and the environment," Ms Metz said.

Ahead of the weekend, VicRoads warned motorists vehicles are more likely to break down, and incorrectly inflated tyres more likely to blow out in extreme heat.

The organisation asked drivers to be aware temperatures can rise to dangerous levels extremely quickly and a few minutes in a closed car enough to result in extreme injuries or death in pets and children.

urn:contentItem:5RB9-PPG1-JD34-V4TD-00000-00Scorcher warning for region2018-01-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Scorcher warning for regionErin Witmitz

THE region could be in for a scorcher at the weekend, with the mercury set to climb above 40 degrees in parts of the Wimmera tomorrow.

The Bureau of Meteorology has forecast a top of 43 degrees in Warracknabeal tomorrow, while Horsham and Nhill will reach 42 degrees, Stawell 41 degrees and Edenhope 40 degrees.

The hot weather has prompted the Country Fire Authority to remind residents to stay safe and alert.

Authority district 17 operations officer Alfred Mason said the fire danger rating would be extreme tomorrow.

"We will have incident control centres open in Ballarat, Ararat and Horsham," he said.

"All positions have been filled for that day.

"There is nothing more we can do now - we're as prepared as we can be."

Mr Mason said the extreme weather would only last for one day.

"It's just one of those days - we are ramping up our actions but if all goes well, it will just be a day of preparedness," he said.

"It will most likely be a total fire ban day as well."

Mr Mason urged Wimmera residents to look after themselves.

"People need to have a plan, and know the plan if something happens," he said.

"If people are travelling, they need to know their environment because there are different fire ratings in different districts.

"Overall, people need to be safe, be ready and have a happy day."

Forest Fire Management Victoria Mallee district manager Phil Murdoch said the weather would be even hotter in the northern parts of the region.

"The forests and parks are already very dry," he said.

"We're urging anyone going camping, especially tomorrow, to be very careful.

"Before you head out, make sure you plan ahead and have an escape route in case you are cut off by a bushfire."

According to the Bureau of Meteorology, Ararat can expect a top of 40 on Saturday while Stawell will be marginally hotter with the temperature expected to reach 41.

The mercury will drop on Saturday night with more pleasant temperatures around the mid-high 20s expected on Sunday to give some respite from the heat.

urn:contentItem:5RB9-PPG1-JD34-V4CY-00000-00South-west on high alert for day of severe fire risk2018-01-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisSouth-west on high alert for day of severe fire riskKate Zwagerman

Saturday is shaping up as the most dangerous day of the summer so far with a forecast severe fire risk and temperatures of up to 39 degrees, fanned by strong winds.

The south-west is tipped to experience its hottest day this summer with the mercury to hit 38 in Warrnambool, 39 in Hamilton and Colac and 36 degrees in Port Fairy.

A total fire ban has been declared for the entire state.

CFA region five operations manager Richard Bourke said the south-west would experience winds of up to 50 kilometres per hour.

"We're facing hot, gusty north to north-westerly wind and a wind change predicted to come through Hamilton to Warrnambool from 2pm-4pm in the afternoon," he said.

Mr Bourke said the conditions would make it harder to bring any fires under control, but said the region's firefighters were well prepared.

"We have in the south-west two incident control centres at Heywood and Warrnambool. The district five CFA co-ordination centre and district four co-ordination centre will also be operating," he said.

"We have water bombers in Casterton and Hamilton and we're supported by other CFA aircraft across the state."

Mr Bourke advised people to have their fire plans ready and for tourists to be aware of their surroundings.

"People in fire-prone areas should consider re-locating for the day or consider enacting their fire plan," he said.

"(For tourists) their biggest source of information will be the place they are staying. They can also download the Vic Emergency app."

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Stephanie Rotarangi urged people to check conditions before entering parks and forests.

"It is essential people stay informed as weather conditions and fire danger can change quickly," Dr Rotarangi said.

"Fire danger ratings are forecast to reach extreme levels in the Mallee and Wimmera forecast districts and severe and very high in other parts of the state.

"These weather conditions mean any fires that start will be much harder to control."

People are also warned that campfires and barbecues can't be lit on total fire ban days.

urn:contentItem:5S5F-2SC1-JD3N-52PS-00000-00SEASIDE CRIME CLUE HUNT2018-04-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5SEASIDE CRIME CLUE HUNTOlivia Shying and Cassie Zervos

A TWO-day police search along the Great Ocean Road has failed to return the evidence police hoped would lead them closer to solving the drive-by shooting of a man in Melbourne.

Four specialist police officers, using metal detectors, spent hours scouring a patch of burned land 500m off Eastern View Lookout near Lorne yesterday looking for evidence linked to a firearm previously seized by investigators.

Muhammed Yucel, 22, was shot and killed while playing video games in the garage of a Keysborough house in May last year and detectives believe the Comanchero bikie gang is responsible.

Police believe Mr Yucel's death was a case of mistaken identity. He died after he was struck in the chest by a bullet, while two other men, aged 23 and 22, received single gunshot wounds and were taken to hospital.

The evidence search along the Great Ocean Road was a surprise twist in the case, and police have not said if they would continue to search other parts of the road.

Forest Fire Management Victoria staff conducted the burn near Lorne on Thursday as detectives watched.

"Investigators are currently in possession of a firearm that has now been forensically linked to the shooting and today's burn is a search for further evidence in relation to that," a Victoria Police spokeswoman said on Thursday.

"They also have information that a grey Toyota Corolla may have travelled to the area around the time of the shooting and would like to hear from anyone who saw this vehicle in the area at the time." A police spokeswoman said late yesterday that nothing was found during the search and that detectives would not return to that site over the weekend.

The search came less than a month after Mr Yucel's family made a plea for information.

His death was the first of two bungled contract killings linked to the Comanchero last year.

In August, Zabi Ezedyar was executed as he visited the Narre Warren home of Mongol-linked criminal Mohammad "Afghan Ali" Keshtiar.In February, former gang member Robert Ale survived a shooting attempt at a Hampton Park tattoo parlour that was linked to jailed Comanchero boss Mick Murray.

urn:contentItem:5S4P-7221-F0JP-W41N-00000-00Bikie hit gun clue2018-04-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 17Bikie hit gun clueMark Buttler

A GUN discarded beside the Great Ocean Road was used by a harebrained hit team in a botched bikie murder plot.

Homicide squad detectives yesterday conducted a controlled burn of a small area of grass at Spout Creek where the weapon was found.

They believe there may be more evidence in the area linked to the mistaken identity killing of Muhamed Yucel in Keysborough.

The recovered gun has been forensically connected to the killing of Mr Yucel, a hardworking young man who was playing computer games with mates in a garage when gunmen opened fire on the night of May 2 last year.

They are suspected of being Comanchero-commissioned shooters assigned to murder a member of the rival Mongols outfit, Farshad Rasooli.

A grey Toyota Corolla seen at the Spout Creek scene at the time of the shooting is thought to be linked to the gun.

A Jeep Cherokee has already been seized from Cranbourne as part of the inquiry. Forest Fire Management Victoria staff conducted the burn near Lorne yesterday as detectives watched. Police will search the scorched area when it cools off.

"Investigators are currently in a possession of a firearm that has now been forensically linked to the shooting and today's burn is a search for further evidence in relation to that," a Victoria Police spokeswoman said.

"They also have information that a grey Toyota Corolla may have travelled to the area around the time of the shooting and would like to hear from anyone who saw this vehicle in the area at the time." It was the first of two bungled contract killings linked to the Comanchero last year.

In August, Zabi Ezedyar was executed as he visited the Narre Warren home of Mongol-linked criminal Mohammad "Afghan Ali" Keshtiar.

The cases came amid a spate of Comanchero-related shootings. In February, former gang member Robert Ale survived a hail of bullets at a Hampton Park tattoo parlour that was linked to jailed Comanchero boss Mick Murray.

There was another attempted murder in Reservoir in August last year believed to be the gang's handiwork.ANYONE WITH INFORMATION CAN CALL CRIME STOPPERS ON 1800 333 000 OR VISIT crimestoppersvic.com.au
