urn:contentItem:5RBY-PK71-JD34-V506-00000-00Campfire to bushfire in minutes2018-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisCampfire to bushfire in minutes

Forest Fire Management Victoria has launched a campaign to remind campers to follow the rules when it comes to campfire safety.

Assistant Chief Fire Officer, Chris Stephenson said: "We want to reduce the number of fires caused by neglected campfires so our message to campers is Don't let your campfire become a bushfire this summer."

"We want people to get out there and enjoy themselves but make campfire safety a priority for their trip by knowing what they can and can't do," Mr Stephenson said.

"In Gippsland we have had far too many bushfires caused by campfire negligence and this is placing the community and firefighters at risk, as well as potentially damaging the environment and affecting industry and recreational users of our public land."

"It takes a lot of time, effort and personnel to respond to a fire, so when campfires escape and could have been prevented by following the rules, it's very frustrating."

Parks Victoria Regional Director, Graeme Baxter said: "In National Parks, campfires can only be lit in designated fireplaces, so if there are no designated fire places, then campfires are not permitted."

"Our rangers regularly patrol parks, forests and reserves to ensure campers are doing the right thing and to educate visitors on campfire safety," Mr Baxter said.

"Before you head out, make sure you plan ahead and check the long-range weather forecast. If in doubt on a hot day, don't light your campfire. "We are asking people to be vigilant about campfire safety and if they see a campfire that doesn't look right or is unattended to call 136 186 or 000 if they see a bushfire."

It is everyone's responsibility to ensure they follow the campfire safety rules:

Under the Forest Act 1958, on the spot fines of up to $476 can be issued for people breaching campfire safety rules and a person can face a maximum penalty of up to $15,872 if the matter is prosecuted in Court. For more information go to bushfire restrictions.

urn:contentItem:5RB3-RF31-F0J6-J05V-00000-00Push for campfire safety this summer with bushfires caused by negligence2018-01-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Push for campfire safety this summer with bushfires caused by negligenceRochelle Kirkham

Forest Fire Management Victoria is urging campers to follow rules for campfire safety this summer, as winds and high temperatures forecast for the state on Saturday will increase bushfire risk.

A severe fire danger rating is in place for the central, north central and south west fire district including Ballarat on Saturday with temperatures expected to reach 39 degrees.

Campfire negligence has caused eight fires in the Grampians region since October, according to Grampians region chief fire officer Peter Kambouris.

CAMPFIRE SAFETY RULES:

Mr Kambouris said the message for campers was "don't let your campfire become a bushfire this summer".

"We are keen for people to get out there and enjoy themselves, but make campfire safety a priority for their trip by knowing what they can and can't do," he said.

"It takes a lot of time, effort and personnel to respond to a fire, so when campfires escape and could have been prevented by following the rules, it's very frustrating."

Campfires can only be lit in designated fire places in national parks.

Campfire safety rules dictate branches and logs on a campfire should be less than one metre long, a campfire should never be left unattended or alight, and it should be completely put out using water, not soil.

Parks Victoria director fire and emergency David Nugent said it was recommended to not light a campfire if in doubt on a hot day.

Parks Victoria rangers will be patrolling forests, parks and reserves to ensure campers are following rules.

On the spot fines of up to $476 can be issued for people breaching campfire safety rules under the Forest Act 1958 and a person can face a maximum penalty of up to $15,872 if the matter is prosecuted in court.

Call 136 186 if you see a campfire that doesn't look right or is unattended or 000 if you see a bushfire.

For more information go to https://www.ffm.vic.gov.au/permits-and-regulations/fire-restrictions-and-regulations.

urn:contentItem:5PDY-DP71-F0J6-J3T0-00000-00Wimmera bushfire risk 'normal' for summer2017-09-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisWimmera bushfire risk 'normal' for summerErin Witmitz

WIMMERA firefighters have encouraged residents to prepare for this year's fire season, despite a wet winter.

The Bushfire and Natural Hazards Co-operative Research Centre has released its Southern Australia Seasonal Bushfire Outlook 2017, which shows the Wimmera will have 'normal' bushfire potential this summer.

This is down from an 'above normal' risk in the region for the past few summers.

The research centre predicts that most of central and eastern Victoria will have a high risk of bushfires for 2017-18.

The report said severe rainfall deficiencies in southern forest areas and the Bureau of Meteorology's outlook for drier and warmer conditions in spring, gave rise to an expectation of above normal fire potential.

"Good prospects for spring growth in the northern and central western grain growing areas present a risk of an early fire season, as these areas are expected to increase biomass during spring and cure during October," the report said.

"This will happen as available soil water becomes depleted."

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Wimmera district manager Glenn Rudolph said while across Victoria the outlook was for an above average bushfire season, the Wimmera had experienced widespread rain across most of the year. "We've had above-average rainfall last month, but despite that, it is difficult to predict the fire risk," he said.

"We are also conscious of the fact that the average season and the rain we have had could increase grass growth in spring.

"The Bureau of Meteorology is also predicting above average temperatures for spring." Mr Rudolph said despite the bushfire outlook, people should always be prepared for the fire season.

"You can never predict what is going to happen and every year there is a risk of bushfires, regardless of the forecast," he said.

"My message to everyone is to be aware of the risks, especially when travelling across the state."

Forest Fire Management Victoria is urging campers to follow rules for campfire safety this summer, as winds and high temperatures forecast for the state on Saturday will increase bushfire risk.

A severe fire danger rating is in place for the central, north central and south west fire district including Ballarat on Saturday with temperatures expected to reach 39 degrees.

Campfire negligence has caused eight fires in the Grampians region since October, according to Grampians region chief fire officer Peter Kambouris.

CAMPFIRE SAFETY RULES:

Mr Kambouris said the message for campers was "don't let your campfire become a bushfire this summer".

"We are keen for people to get out there and enjoy themselves, but make campfire safety a priority for their trip by knowing what they can and can't do," he said.

"It takes a lot of time, effort and personnel to respond to a fire, so when campfires escape and could have been prevented by following the rules, it's very frustrating."

Campfires can only be lit in designated fire places in national parks.

Campfire safety rules dictate branches and logs on a campfire should be less than one metre long, a campfire should never be left unattended or alight, and it should be completely put out using water, not soil.

Parks Victoria director fire and emergency David Nugent said it was recommended to not light a campfire if in doubt on a hot day.

Parks Victoria rangers will be patrolling forests, parks and reserves to ensure campers are following rules.

On the spot fines of up to $476 can be issued for people breaching campfire safety rules under the Forest Act 1958 and a person can face a maximum penalty of up to $15,872 if the matter is prosecuted in court.

Call 136 186 if you see a campfire that doesn't look right or is unattended or 000 if you see a bushfire.

For more information go to https://www.ffm.vic.gov.au/permits-and-regulations/fire-restrictions-and-regulations.

urn:contentItem:5RB9-PPG1-JD34-V419-00000-00Warnings issued as hottest day in 11 months predicted2018-01-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisWarnings issued as hottest day in 11 months predictedSophie Boyd

Victoria is in a state of total fire ban, with Saturday forecast to be the hottest day on the Border or North East in almost 11 months.

Gusts of 20 to 30 kilometres an hour have also been predicted.

The Bureau of Meterology forecast most Border and North East towns would reach 41 degrees on Saturday and 38 on Sunday, before temperatures return to the mid-30s.

It will be the first time the temperature jump over the 40-degree mark since February 10 last year, when the mercury spiked at 43.7 degrees.

A NSW's Rural Fire Service spokesman said they were watching forecasts, especially wind levels, closely in areas of severe fire danger but no total fire ban had been declared yet.

Communities have already felt the impact of the impending heat with one small town's big event, the Dederang Cup, abandoned for the first time in at least 63 years, due the weather.

A Victorian government Heat Health Alert issued for parts of the state urges residents to drink water and check on vulnerable people.

Forest Fire Management Victoria warned residents it is illegal to light a campfire on a total fire ban day.

Assistant Chief Fire Officer for the Hume Region Gill Metz said the region was expecting wind gusts up to 30 kilometres an hour across Saturday.

"Historically in the Hume region, we've had far too many bushfires caused by campfire negligence and this is placing the community, firefighters and the environment at risk," she said.

"It's critically important campfire safety is a priority."

Already this year a number of unattended campfires were located and extinguished.

"Under the right conditions, anyone of these campfires could have become a bushfire and threaten lives, property and the environment," Ms Metz said.

Ahead of the weekend, VicRoads warned motorists vehicles are more likely to break down, and incorrectly inflated tyres more likely to blow out in extreme heat.

The organisation asked drivers to be aware temperatures can rise to dangerous levels extremely quickly and a few minutes in a closed car enough to result in extreme injuries or death in pets and children.

urn:contentItem:5RB9-PPG1-JD34-V4F9-00000-00South-west on high alert for day of severe fire risk2018-01-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3South-west on high alert for day of severe fire riskKate Zwagerman

Saturday is shaping up as the most dangerous day of the summer so far with a forecast severe fire risk and temperatures of up to 39 degrees, fanned by strong winds.

The south-west is tipped to experience its hottest day this summer with the mercury to hit 38 in Warrnambool, 39 in Hamilton and Colac and 36 degrees in Port Fairy.

A total fire ban has been declared for the entire state.

CFA region five operations manager Richard Bourke said the south-west would experience winds of up to 50 kilometres per hour.

"We're facing hot, gusty north to north-westerly wind and a wind change predicted to come through Hamilton to Warrnambool from 2pm-4pm in the afternoon," he said.

Mr Bourke said the conditions would make it harder to bring any fires under control, but said the region's firefighters were well prepared.

"We have in the south-west two incident control centres at Heywood and Warrnambool. The district five CFA co-ordination centre and district four co-ordination centre will also be operating," he said.

"We have water bombers in Casterton and Hamilton and we're supported by other CFA aircraft across the state."

Mr Bourke advised people to have their fire plans ready and for tourists to be aware of their surroundings.

"People in fire-prone areas should consider re-locating for the day or consider enacting their fire plan," he said.

"(For tourists) their biggest source of information will be the place they are staying. They can also download the Vic Emergency app."

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Stephanie Rotarangi urged people to check conditions before entering parks and forests.

"It is essential people stay informed as weather conditions and fire danger can change quickly," Dr Rotarangi said.

"Fire danger ratings are forecast to reach extreme levels in the Mallee and Wimmera forecast districts and severe and very high in other parts of the state.

"These weather conditions mean any fires that start will be much harder to control."

People are also warned that campfires and barbecues can't be lit on total fire ban days.

urn:contentItem:5V51-6631-JD3N-53Y7-00000-00ADDY READERS HAVE THEIR SAY - LETTERS AND TEXTS2019-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 17ADDY READERS HAVE THEIR SAY - LETTERS AND TEXTS

LARA PIECE LEFT ME A BIT BAFFLED ON THE NUMBERS THE article Remembering Lara (GA 5/1) did not balance with my memory, prompting me to investigate further.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's website states 17 deaths occurred on the highway at Lara as a result of the fires of December 14, 1972, with that fire causing a total of 23 deaths, not 18 as stated in your article.

This fits my recollection, we can't all be wrong after 50 years. I then read on to compare the two fires: The 1972 December 14 fire burned for 12 days, destroyed 230 houses, 21 other buildings more than 12,000 stock across 12,140 hectares - not that big compared to many other fires on that site.

The site goes on to say the fire on January 8, 1969, burned 250,000 hectares, with no mention of human loss, number of days duration, houses destroyed or stock loss.

I remain confused.

I now wonder which source is the accurate one?

Michael Tucker, Winchelsea [ED'S NOTE: The fire on January 8, 1969, killed a total of 18 people - 17 on the highway and one other person in the township of Lara.]

IT'S HIGH TIME OUR JIMMY WAS GIVEN A BOARD SEAT IT'S no surprise Geelong Football Club CEO Brian Cook thinks it's too soon Jimmy Bartel to given a seat on the Cats board (GA 7/1).

Fancy having a football person on the board, fancy bringing new blood to the board, fancy bringing one of our most decorated players on, to learn and become a face of the club, something which is long overdue.

Perhaps that is part of the problem on the field. There are no new faces, new ideas, innovation or changes at the club, not even an election for board members.

Rennis Witham, Williamstown

FIREWORKS COST US A LOT MORE THAN JUST MONEY THE concerning issue about the New Year's Eve fireworks display is not about the cost. $3.4 million is neither here nor there in the big picture.

The problem is the metal particulates, strontium, perchlorate, barium and other dangerous toxins just to name a few which are released into the atmosphere.

All of these are harmful to humans and animals, remain in the air for days and inevitably descend on waterways and oceans.

Given that every major city in the world now has huge fireworks displays to ring in the new year, this is a global pollution problem.

It is a problem that doesn't have to occur as there are eco-friendly alternatives which are just as spectacular and do not pollute.

Greg Lawes, Dingley Village

TEXT TALK I HOPE Dylan Hartwick (GA 7/1) gives his victim half of his pay, I bet not. The laws have to change.

Unbelievable,Leopold

urn:contentItem:5N8V-8X01-F0J6-J33G-00000-00Postponed planned burns to go ahead2017-04-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:35:22ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Postponed planned burns to go ahead

A series of postponed planned burns will go ahead this week if weather conditions permit.

Residents around Ballarat East, Alfredton and the surrounding area may see smoke on Wednesday as more than 30 CFA volunteers participate in a planned burn training camp.

CFA west region vegetation management officer Tony Brady said the training exercise would be an opportunity for volunteers to learn the skills and techniques required to conduct fuel reduction burns.

"As part of our training exercise, we'll be conducting two planned burns on Wednesday we will be burning grasslands at Victoria Park," Mr Brady said.

"CFA holds burn camps every year in different locations to build volunteer fire suppression and fuel management skills.

The planned burn at Victoria Park has been requested by Ballarat City Council. It will aid fuel reduction and support support environmental regeneration.

The other burn at Pax Hill, on April 22, is focused on fuel reduction and protection of the camp.

"All efforts will be made to reduce an impact on the community however there will be smoke in the area of the burns," Mr Brady said.

"The burns are significant as they are in highly populated areas and while they may cause some inconvenience, they will provide long term benefits for the community."

Residents will see fire trucks moving around the area during burning and for safety reasons are asked to remain clear of the burns and around trucks.

Up to 40 New Zealand firefighters will fly into Victoria next week to help with the autumn planned Forest Fire Management burning.

New Zealand firefighters will assist as services in other states remain tied up with their own commitments.
